1.q_string:
One mole of an ideal gas at \(300 \mathrm{~K}\) is heated at constant volume \(\left(\mathrm{V}_{1}\right)\) until its temperature is doubled, then it is expanded isothermally till it reaches the original pressure. Finally, the gas is cooled at the constant pressure till the system reaches to the half of original volume \(\left(\mathrm{V}_{1 / 2}\right)\). The total work done \((\mathrm{W})\) is \(10 \mathrm{x}\) calories. Determine \(\mathrm{x}\).

[Use,\(\ln 2=0.70, \mathrm{R}=2 \mathrm{cal} \mathrm{K}^{-1} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}\)]

One mole of soda ash dissolves in water with the evolution of \(25kJ\) of heat. Dissolution of \(1 \mathrm{~mol}\) of the hydrate crystals in water resulted in the absorption of \(67 \mathrm{~kJ}\) of heat. The heat released due to hydration of soda ash is:

The heat of formation of \(\mathrm{HCl}\) at \(348 \mathrm{~K}\) from the following data will be:

\(\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{H}_{2}(\mathrm{~g})+\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{Cl}_{2}(\mathrm{~g}) \rightarrow \mathrm{HCl}(\mathrm{g}) ; \Delta_{\mathrm{r}} \mathrm{H}_{298}=-22060 \mathrm{cal}\)

The mean heat capacities over this temperature range are:

\(\mathrm{H}_{2}(\mathrm{~g}), \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{P}}=6.82 \mathrm{cal}~ \mathrm{mol}^{-1} \mathrm{~K}^{-1} ; \mathrm{Cl}_{2}(\mathrm{~g}), \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{P}}=7.71 \mathrm{cal}~ \mathrm{mol}^{-1} \mathrm{~K}^{-1}\) 

\(\mathrm{HCl}(\mathrm{g}), \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{P}}=6.81 \mathrm{cal}~ \mathrm{mol}^{-1} \mathrm{~K}^{-1}\)
A tightly closed thermos flask contains some ice cubes. This is an example of:
A closed system is one in which ______.
q_option: Mass does not cross boundaries of the system, though energy may do so
Mass crosses the boundary but not the energy
Neither mass nor energy crosses the boundaries of the system
Both energy and mass cross the boundaries of the system

1.q_string: A monoatomic ideal gas goes through a process in which, the ratio of \(P\) to \(V\) at any instance is constant and equal to unity. The molar heat capacity of gas is
When 1 mole of oxalic acid is treated with excess of \(\mathrm{NaOH}\) in dilute aqueous solution, \(106 \mathrm{~kJ}\) of heat liberated. Predict the enthalpy of ionization of the acid.

On the basis of the following thermochemical data,

\({\left[\Delta f G^{\circ} \mathrm{H}^{+}(a q)=0\right]}\)

\(\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}(l) \rightarrow \mathrm{H}^{+}(a q)+\mathrm{OH}^{-}(a q) ; \Delta H=57.32 \mathrm{~kJ}\)

\(\mathrm{H}_{2}(\mathrm{~g})+\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{O}_{2}(\mathrm{~g}) \rightarrow \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}(l) ; \quad \Delta H=-286.02 \mathrm{~kJ}\)

The value of enthalpy of formation of \(\mathrm{OH}^{-}\)ion at \(25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\) is:
Hess' law states that:
q_option: The standard enthalpy of an overall reaction is the sum of the enthalpy changes in individual reactions.
Enthalpy of formation of a compound is same as the enthalpy of decomposition of the compound into constituent elements, but with opposite sign.
At constant temperature the pressure of a gas is inversely proportional to its volume.
The mass of a gas dissolved per litre of a solvent is proportional to the pressure of the gas in equilibrium with the solution.

1.q_string: For the reaction, \(\mathrm{X}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{4}(l) \rightarrow 2 \mathrm{XO}_{2}(\mathrm{~g}) \Delta U=2.1 \mathrm{k}\) cal, \(\triangle S=\) \(20 \mathrm{calK}^{-1}\) at \(300 \mathrm{~K}\). Hence, \(\triangle G\) is:

Consider the following process

\(\Delta H(k J / m o l)\)

\(\frac{1}{2} A \rightarrow B+50\)

\(3 B \rightarrow 3 C+D-125\)

\(E+A \rightarrow 2 D+350\)

\(\text { For } B+D \rightarrow E+2 C, \Delta H \text { will be: }\)
In the reaction for the transition of carbon in the diamond form to carbon in the graphite form, \(\Delta H\) is \(-453.5\) cal. This points out that:

A mercury thermometer was first placed in melting ice and the length of mercury column was observed to be \(10 mm\); when it was placed in steam, the length of the column was \(250 mm\). When placed in tap water, the length of the column was \(58 mm\). The temperature of the tap water is:
Then the possible heat of formation of methane will be:

When two moles of an ideal gas \(\left(C_{p, m}=\frac{5}{2} R\right)\) is heated from \(300 K\) to \(600 K\) at constant pressure, the change in entropy of gas \((\Delta S)\) is:

For an ideal gas, consider only \(P - V\) work in going from an initial state \(X\) to the final state \(Z\). The final state \(Z\) can be reached by either of the two paths shown in the figure. Which of the following choice(S) is (are) correct? [take \(\Delta S\) as change in entropy and w as work done].

{{A 972.PNG}}
q_option: \(\Delta S _{ x \rightarrow z }=\Delta S _{ x \rightarrow y }+\Delta S _{ y \rightarrow z }\)
\(W _{ x \rightarrow y \rightarrow z }= W _{ x \rightarrow y }\)
\(W _{ x \rightarrow z }= W _{ x \rightarrow y }+ W _{ y \rightarrow z }\)

1.q_string: \(\Delta H _{ f }^{\circ}\) of water is \(-285.8 kJ mol ^{-1}\). If the enthalpy of neutralization of monoacid strong base is \(-57.3 kJ mol -1\), \(\Delta H _{ f }^{\circ}\) of \(OH ^{-}\)ion will be:
Which one of the following is not a state function?

An ideal gas is subjected to a cyclic process \(A B C D\) as depicted in the \(p\) - \(V\) diagram given below:

Which of the following curves represents the equivalent cyclic process?
Which law of thermodynamics states that if two thermodynamic systems are each in thermal equilibrium with a third, then they are in thermal equilibrium with each other.

\(\Delta C _{ p }\) for a reaction is \(2.0+0.2 T\) cal \(deg ^{-1}\). Its enthalpy of reaction at \(10 K\) is \(-14.2 kcal mol ^{-1}\). Its negative enthalpy of reaction at \(100 K\) in \(kcal mol ^{-1} will ^{\text {it }}\) be nearly:

A cylinder containing an ideal gas ( \(0.1 mol\) of \(1.0 dm ^{3}\) ) is in thermal equilibrium with a large volume of \(0 . 5\) molal aqueous solution of ethylene glycol at its freezing point. If the stoppers \(S_{1}\) and \(S_{2}\) (as shown in the figure) are suddenly withdrawn, the volume of the gas in litres after equilibrium is achieved will be _________.

(Given, \(K_{ f }\) (water) \(=2.0 Kkgmol ^{-1}, R =0.08 dm ^{3} atmK ^{-1} mol ^{-1}\) )
The factors which influence the heat of reaction are:
q_option: Whether the reaction is carried out at constant pressure or constant temperature,

1.q_string: When \(100 mL\) of \(1.0 M HCl\) was mixed with \(100 mL\) of \(1.0 M NaOH\) in an insulated beaker at constant pressure, a temperature increase of \(5.7^{\circ} C\) was measured for the beaker and its contents (Expt.\(1\)). Because the enthalpy of neutralization of a strong acid with a strong base is a constant \(\left(-57.0 k J ~ m o l ^{-1}\right)\), this experiment could be used to measure the calorimeter constant. In a second experiment (Expt. \(2\)), \(100 mL\) of \(2.0 M\) acetic acid \(\left( K _{ a }=2.0 \times 10^{-5}\right)\) was mixed with \(100 mL\) of \(1.0 M\) \(NaOH\) (under identical conditions to Expt. 1) where a temperature rise of \(5.6^{\circ} C\) was measured. (Consider heat capacity of all solutions as \(4.2 J ^{-1} K ^{-1}\) and density of all solutions as \(1.0 g mL { }^{-1}\) ) Enthalpy of dissociation (in \(k J m o l ^{-1}\) ) of acetic acid obtained from the Expt. \(2\) is:

A sample containing two moles of \(CO _{2}( g )\) occupies a fixed volume of \(16.10 L\) at \(300 K\) when supplied with \(2.356 kJ\) of heat its temperature rises to \(340 K\). Assume \(CO _{2}( g )\) described by Van der Waals' behaviour. Calculate enthalpy change \(\Delta H\) in \(k J\) and express in decimal number. (take 1 Lt. \(a t m =0.1 k J\) and \(b =5 \times 10-2 L mole ^{-1}, R =0.08 L a atm m ^{-1} K ^{-1} \text { ) }\)

One mole of a monatomic gas at pressure \(2~ atm , 279 K\) is taken to final pressure \(4~ atm\) by a reversible path described by \(\frac{P}{V} =\) constant. Calculate the magnitude of \(\frac{\Delta E}{w}\) for the process.

The lattice energy of solid \(KCl\) is \(181\) \(kcal / mol\) and the enthalpy of dissolution of \(KCl\) in \(H _{2} O\) is \(1.0\) \(kcal / mol\). If the hydration enthalpies of \(K ^{\oplus}\) and \(Cl ^{\ominus}\) ions are in the ratio of \(2: 1\), then the enthalpy of hydration of \(K ^{\oplus}\) is \(-20 x\) \(kcal / mol\). What is the value of \(x\)?

The enthalpy change involved in the oxidation of glucose is \(-2880 k J ~ m o l ^{-1} .25 \%\) of this energy is available for muscular work. If \(100 k J\) muscular work is needed to walk one kilometre, what is the maximum distance that a person will be able to walk after eating \(120 g\) of glucose?

One mole of an ideal gas is taken from a to \(b\) along two paths denoted by the solid and dashed line as shown in the graph below. If the work done along the solid line(reversible isothermal process) path is \(w _{ s }\) and that along the dotted line path is \(w_{d}\), then the integer closest to the ratio \(\frac{w_{d}}{w_{s}}\) is __________.

Take \(PV =3~ atm - L\) for calculation of work done in revrsible isothermal process.
